d under the company's management of change program.

Employee Training - Personnel performing specific tasks, which affect the processing system, must be qualified to perform their assigned tasks. The company utilizes an established training program that ensures the training and competency of employees, whose jobs require them to perform work, which affect the processing system. 

Mechanical Integrity - Under the PSM program, equipment used to process, store, or handle flammable or toxic materials has to be designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the release of such chemicals. As required, elements of the mechanical integrity program include identifying and categorizing equipment and instrumentation as faulty or potentially faulty, inspections and tests and their frequency; maintenance procedures; training of maintenance personnel; criteria for acceptable test results; and documentation of manufacturer recommendations for equipment and instrumentation.

Management of Change - Contemplated changes to a process must be evaluated thoroughly to fully assess their impact on employee safety and health and to determine needed changes 
to operating procedures. The company has established and implemented procedures to manage changes (except for replacements in kind) to process chemicals, technology equipment and procedures, and changes to facilities that affect the existing manufacturing system.

Pre-Startup Safety Review - As one of the requirements of CalARP/RMP, FMI is required to perform a pre-startup safety review for new facilities, and for modified facilities when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information. A PHA will be performed prior to start up for new processes that require a hazardous material above the regulatory threshold. For existing processes that have been shutdown for turnaround or modification, company policy ensures that any changes other than replacement in kind made to

were considered in the evaluation: 1) the process design; 2) process technology; 3) process changes; 4) operational and maintenance activities and procedures; 5) non-routine activities and procedures; 6) emergency preparedness plans and procedures; 7) training programs; and 8) other elements that affect the process. The various lines of defense that have been incorporated into the design and operation of the process to prevent or mitigate the release of hazardous chemicals have been evaluated and strengthened to assure their effectiveness at each level. FMI uses the proactive identification, evaluation, and mitigation for prevention of chemical releases that could occur as a result of failures in process, procedures, or equipment. The elements of the FMI's accidental release prevention program are summarized as follows:

Process Safety Information - This includes complete and accurate written information concerning process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment essential to the company's PSM program and to a process hazard analysis. The process safety information includes information pertaining to the hazards of flammable compressed gases and the technology and equipment of the NGL system.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) - Is an organized and systematic effort to identify and analyze the significance of potential hazards associated with the processing or handling of flammable or toxic materials. The PHA provides information that will assist the company and its employees in making decisions for improving safety and reducing the consequences of unwanted or unplanned releases of flammable or toxic materials. The PHA has been updated and can be found in Appendix J. 

Operating Procedures - As part of the PSM program, all procedures for operating and maintaining the process equipment are documented and accessible to employees whose work involves this equipment. As needed, changes or updates to the processing system operating procedures are incorporate

the process during shutdown go through the management of change process. 

Compliance Audits - Periodically, FMI performs an audit of their RMP program as required by the CalARP standard. An audit is a technique used to gather sufficient facts and information, including statistical information, to verify compliance with the CalARP standards. The audit includes an evaluation of the design and effectiveness of the system and a field inspection of the safety and health conditions and practices to verify that the program elements are effectively implemented.

Incident Investigation - A crucial part of FMI's program is a thorough investigation of incidents to identify the chain of events and causes so that corrective measures can be developed and implemented. Accordingly, FMI has an incident investigation program that requires the investigation of each incident that resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in, release of a flammable or toxic material.

Employee Participation Plan - FMI has developed written procedures to include employees in the development, implementation, and management of these program elements.

Hot Work & Safe Work Practices 
- FMI has established safe work practices in place to ensure worker and process safety. Details of both hot work and safe work practices are detailed in the PSM. 

Contractor Safety - FMI, in following OSHA's PSM Guidelines, requires that a contractor's safety program be evaluated, that contractor employees be trained regarding potential process hazards and emergency procedures, and that appropriate records are maintained. Contractors who perform work in and around processes that involve flammable gases or liquids are certified by FMI to accomplish the desired job tasks without compromising the safety and health of any employee at the facility.

External Events Analysis Information - Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, §2745.7(q); the following

external events analysis information shall be submitted:  
-The types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA Section 2760.2 or Hazard Review Section 2755.2.  
   During the May 2012 PHA a broad list of external events was considered by the Team.  General events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of anhydrous or aqueous ammonia were addressed.  The External Events that were considered credible include, but are not limited to, earthquake, vandalism, sabotage, external fire, human error/misoperation, and vehicle impact. 
-The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered. If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the AA to determine what is required. If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.
-A safety walk-down was performed June 4th, 2009.  All findings are documented in the ¿Process Hazard Analysis¿ report.
-The magnitudes of the external events considered are detailed within the PHA Worksheets and were qualitatively risk-ranked by the PHA Team.
   For each external event, with a potential to create a release of a regulated substance that will reach an endpoint offsite, apply 
1) The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the PHA;
2) Major hazards identified;
3) Process controls in use;
4) Mitigation systems in use;
5) Monitoring and detection systems in use; and,
6) Changes since the last Hazard Review (HR) or PHA
   Refer to Section 7.4 of the RMP  2004 Submit Printout for the required PHA information.
-The date of the most recent field verification that equipment is installed and maintained as designed.
  A field verification of equipment was conducted on June 4, 2009.

Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 

The various lines of defense that have been incorporated by FMI into

SM manual is maintained as a living document, its continuing updating provides a means of sustaining its original objective to improve the health and safety of individuals associated with the ammonia process.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

It is the policy of Freeport McMoRan (FMI) that its employees, environment, property, and the general public be protected from any harm that may occur as a result of its operations. To achieve this end, FMI strives to operate its facilities in compliance with applicable federal, state, and local safety, health, and environmental regulations. 

FMI implements its emergency response policies to comply with the overall corporate policy of providing its workers with a safe workplace and of minimizing risk to the public. The safety of emergency and non-affected personnel is the highest priority; therefore, all procedures must be implemented in the appropriate manner (e.g., safely executed rescue, and medical activities). Protection of the environment is also a high priority. Once the issues of life, safety, and the environment are addressed, the secondary issues of property conservation and business recovery may be considered.

Facility Description

The Inglewood Field is located at 5640 South Fairfax Ave in metropolitan Los Angeles, seven miles west-southwest of downtown Los Angeles. The field covers most of the Baldwin Hills. These hills project above the surrounding coastal plain by 300-400 feet. The Field is located in an unincorporated portion of Los Angeles County, except for a small northwest portion which lies within Culver City. 

The gas plant is situated near the north end of the Field. The Field is bordered in this area by the Kenneth Hahn State Recreational Area. The nearest public roadway, La Cienega Boulevard, runs through the middle of the Inglewood Field in a north-south direction. The Kenneth Hahn State Recreational Area is approximately 900 feet (.17 mile) to the north. The State Recreation Area is considered a public receptor under the RMP regulation. 

The gas plant is designed to convert sweet field gas into pipeline quality sales gas and natural gas liqu

ids (natural gas liquids and propane). 


System Process Summary

Major process steps include the following:

a) First stage compression and dewatering (1.3 psig to 36.3 psig);
b) Second stage compression and dewatering (36.3 psig to 150 psig);
c) Third stage compression and dewatering (150 psig to 475 psig);
d) DEA CO2 removal and odor control;
e) NGL separation, storage, and shipping (LTS Unit); and
f) Safety relief (PSVs, vents, and flare). 

Two LPG bullets each have a working capacity of 22,500 gallons. The natural gas liquids (NGL) storage tank has a working capacity of 56,000 gallons.

Regulated Substances

The California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP) regulations apply to a stationary source with a process that has more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance. The two regulated substances of concern at FMI Inglewood Gas Plant are liguefied propane gas (LPG) and liquefied natural gas (NGLs). The CalARP threshold quantity and the EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP) threshold for these substances is 10,000 lbs. 

There are no regulated toxic substances present at the facility in excess of the threshold quantities under the regulations.

The following flammable substances are present over the threshold quantity: 

Propane CAS # 74-98-6 ( lbs. - based on 75% working capacity)
Flammable Mixture
Butane CAS # 106-97-8 ( lbs ¿ based on 75% working capacity)

Under Title 19 Division 2 Chapter 4.5, Table 3 State Regulated Substances List and Threshold Quantities for Accidental Release Prevention, the propane and butane threshold quantities are 10,000 pounds. 
Under EPA Clean Air Act 112® Title 40 CFR Part 68 Table 4 Federal Regulated Substances list and Threshold Quantities for Accidental Release Prevention, the propane and butane threshold quantities are 10,000 pounds.
